data.vignette: In an inpatient hospice unit with a fixed number of beds, a 62-year-old with metastatic cancer has severe, refractory pain and agitation. Symptoms improve only with continuous IV medications and frequent bedside nursing, which the home hospice team cannot provide. Hospital policy allows extended stays only with medical director approval; several new hospice referrals are waiting for admission. The hospice medical director must decide whether to keep the patient inpatient for ongoing intensive symptom control or arrange discharge to home with intermittent visits and oral medications to open the bed.
data.choice_1: Approve an extended inpatient hospice stay with continuous IV medications and intensive nursing.
data.choice_2: Discharge to home hospice with less intensive symptom management to free the inpatient bed.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Soften clinically deterministic language that makes one option medically mandatory. Replace “Symptoms improve only with continuous IV medications and frequent bedside nursing, which the home hospice team cannot provide” with “Symptoms are best controlled with continuous IV medications and frequent bedside nursing; home hospice can offer oral/SC regimens and intermittent visits but control may be less reliable.” Keep benefits/harms qualitative and fixed, but avoid implying discharge guarantees uncontrolled suffering.

temporal_definition.suggested_changes: Add a clear decision timeframe tied to operations, e.g., “A bed decision is needed today before evening admissions” or “within the next 4 hours as new referrals arrive,” so urgency is explicit.

key_information.suggested_changes: Add only the missing essentials that drive the ethical tension: patient decision-making capacity and stated preference (e.g., wants to die at home vs wants to stay inpatient), and whether a surrogate/family can support home care. Remove/avoid extra policy wording if needed to stay ≤100 words after adding these facts.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Make both choices clinically and ethically defensible by clarifying that home discharge is not clearly cruel/unsafe: (1) state the patient prefers home and accepts potential symptom worsening, or that IV meds can be converted to SC/oral with uncertain adequacy; (2) avoid “cannot provide” and “improve only,” which make inpatient care the only reasonable medical option. This will preserve a real justice-vs-patient-centered-care dilemma.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Make Choice 2 clinically and ethically more defensible so it is not obviously worse care. For example: add that the patient strongly prefers to be at home, has reliable 24/7 family caregivers, and the home hospice team can provide rapid escalation (e.g., daily nurse visits, on-call support) and subcutaneous/oral meds that will likely keep symptoms acceptable though less tightly controlled than IV/nurse-intensive inpatient care. Also strengthen the competing justice claim by specifying that one or more waiting referrals have similarly uncontrolled symptoms or no safe home setting, so keeping this bed directly prevents timely care for others. Consider removing/softening ‘hospital policy allows extended stays only with medical director approval’ so the dilemma is not framed as compliance with policy rather than a values tradeoff.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove framing that implies one option is preferable. Rephrase “to open the bed” to a neutral descriptor such as “to make the bed available for other pending admissions.” Replace “severe, refractory” with “severe” unless refractoriness is essential, and avoid implying home care is inadequate by stating “home hospice can provide intermittent visits; continuous IV infusion is not available in that setting.”

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Trim setting/policy details and remove redundancies. Combine policy/waitlist into one clause. Ensure all facts needed for the ethical tension are present without extra: e.g., omit “frequent bedside nursing” if already implied by “continuous IV medications,” or specify only one. Keep ≤100 words by shortening sentences.

Remove/avoid extra policy wording if needed to stay ≤100 words after adding these facts.

This will preserve a real justice-vs-patient-centered-care dilemma.

feedback.stylistic:
ethical_neutrality: Remove framing that implies one option is preferable. Rephrase “to open the bed” to a neutral descriptor such as “to make the bed available for other pending admissions.” Replace “severe, refractory” with “severe” unless refractoriness is essential, and avoid implying home care is inadequate by stating “home hospice can provide intermittent visits; continuous IV infusion is not available in that setting.”

Ensure all facts needed for the ethical tension are present without extra: e.g., omit “frequent bedside nursing” if already implied by “continuous IV medications,” or specify only one. Keep ≤100 words by shortening sentences.

data.vignette: You are the attending on an 8-bed inpatient hospice unit. A man with metastatic lung cancer has severe dyspnea and pain, currently best controlled with a continuous IV infusion and frequent dose adjustments. He has decision-making capacity and repeatedly asks to go home to die; his partner and adult daughter can provide round-the-clock care, and home hospice can provide oral/subcutaneous medications, daily nurse visits, and on-call support, though symptom control may be less reliable. Two new referrals with uncontrolled symptoms and no safe home setting may arrive tonight. You must decide today whether to keep his bed.
data.choice_1: Continue inpatient hospice care to maintain the most reliable symptom control, even if it delays admission of pending referrals.
data.choice_2: Discharge home with hospice and family support, accepting potentially less reliable symptom control to make a bed available for pending referrals.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove residual prognostic/clinical uncertainty language and make the clinical tradeoff a fixed qualitative fact. Edit: change “though symptom control may be less reliable” to “though symptom control at home will be less reliable than inpatient IV titration.” Also avoid comparative superlatives that bias the choice; change “best controlled” to “controlled with continuous IV infusion requiring frequent titration that cannot be provided at home.”

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Reduce the clinical-asymmetry that makes discharge look unsafe/medically inferior. Rephrase to show home symptom control is feasible but comes with real risk/tradeoffs (e.g., replace “best controlled with a continuous IV infusion and frequent dose adjustments” with “currently controlled on an infusion; the team could transition him to a subcutaneous pump/oral regimen for home, but titration would be slower and breakthrough distress is possible”). Also make the justice pressure less speculative by making the incoming need more concrete (e.g., change “may arrive tonight” to “are waiting in the ED for the next available inpatient hospice bed, and no other beds are available in the region today”). Finally, add that the patient understands and accepts the home-management limitations to keep both options ethically defensible rather than one clearly ‘wrong.’

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove comparative/biasing phrasing that implies one option is clinically superior. For example, change “currently best controlled” to “currently controlled with a continuous IV infusion and frequent titration,” and change “most reliable symptom control”/“less reliable” to neutral wording such as “more intensive titration available inpatient” vs “medication routes and monitoring are more limited at home.” Consider changing “go home to die” to “die at home.”

feedback.clinical: neutralize_clinical_considerations: Remove residual prognostic/clinical uncertainty language and make the clinical tradeoff a fixed qualitative fact. Edit: change “though symptom control may be less reliable” to “though symptom control at home will be less reliable than inpatient IV titration.” Also avoid comparative superlatives that bias the choice; change “best controlled” to “controlled with continuous IV infusion requiring frequent titration that cannot be provided at home.”
feedback.ethical: decision_equipoise: Reduce the clinical-asymmetry that makes discharge look unsafe/medically inferior. Rephrase to show home symptom control is feasible but comes with real risk/tradeoffs (e.g., replace “best controlled with a continuous IV infusion and frequent dose adjustments” with “currently controlled on an infusion; the team could transition him to a subcutaneous pump/oral regimen for home, but titration would be slower and breakthrough distress is possible”). Also make the justice pressure less speculative by making the incoming need more concrete (e.g., change “may arrive tonight” to “are waiting in the ED for the next available inpatient hospice bed, and no other beds are available in the region today”). Finally, add that the patient understands and accepts the home-management limitations to keep both options ethically defensible rather than one clearly ‘wrong.’
feedback.stylistic: ethical_neutrality: Remove comparative/biasing phrasing that implies one option is clinically superior. For example, change “currently best controlled” to “currently controlled with a continuous IV infusion and frequent titration,” and change “most reliable symptom control”/“less reliable” to neutral wording such as “more intensive titration available inpatient” vs “medication routes and monitoring are more limited at home.” Consider changing “go home to die” to “die at home.”

data.vignette: You are the inpatient hospice physician for a man with end-stage cancer and severe breathlessness. His symptoms are currently controlled on a continuous IV opioid infusion with frequent titration; this level of adjustment cannot be provided at home. He strongly wants to die at home, understands that home monitoring and medication routes are more limited, and accepts the possibility of distress before doses can be adjusted. Two patients with uncontrolled symptoms are waiting in the ED for the next inpatient hospice bed, and no other beds are available in the region today. You must decide.
data.choice_1: Keep him inpatient on the IV infusion and defer discharge until his symptoms can be managed without frequent titration.
data.choice_2: Discharge him home now with a feasible home regimen and support plan, accepting slower titration and possible breakthrough distress.

data.vignette: You are the inpatient hospice physician for a man with end-stage cancer and severe breathlessness. His symptoms are currently controlled on a continuous IV opioid infusion with frequent titration; this level of adjustment cannot be provided at home. He strongly wants to die at home, understands that home monitoring and medication routes are more limited, and accepts the possibility of distress before doses can be adjusted. Two patients with uncontrolled symptoms are waiting in the ED for the next inpatient hospice bed, and no other beds are available in the region today. You must decide.

choice_1.choice: Keep him inpatient on the IV infusion and defer discharge until his symptoms can be managed without frequent titration.

choice_2.choice: Discharge him home now with a feasible home regimen and support plan, accepting slower titration and possible breakthrough distress.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Make the competing values explicit in the vignette: (1) patient’s informed, persistent preference for home death despite higher risk of dyspnea/distress due to slower titration; (2) clinician’s duty to provide safe symptom control and avoid foreseeable suffering; (3) scarcity/justice: keeping this bed prevents admission of other actively suffering patients. Clarify there is no way to safely replicate IV titration at home today and that rapid return to inpatient hospice may not be possible if distress escalates.

data.vignette:
A 68-year-old patient with end-stage COPD and metastatic lung cancer is admitted to an inpatient hospice unit for refractory dyspnea and anxiety. Over the past 24 hours, their symptoms have required frequent IV opioid and anxiolytic titration by nursing staff to prevent panic and air hunger. The patient is decisional, has completed advance directives, and repeatedly states: “I want to die at home today,” even after the team explains the trade-offs.

The hospice physician explains that, with current resources, there is no way to safely replicate rapid IV titration at home today: the home hospice agency can provide scheduled oral/subcutaneous medications and intermittent nurse visits, but cannot provide continuous bedside monitoring or rapid dose adjustments. The physician also warns that if severe distress recurs at home, a rapid return to the inpatient unit may not be possible because the unit is at capacity and the next available bed is uncertain.

Meanwhile, the charge nurse notes that two other patients in the community with uncontrolled pain and agitation are awaiting admission, and keeping this bed occupied may delay care for them. The patient’s family is willing to provide care at home but is anxious about managing sudden dyspnea.

The team must decide whether to honor the patient’s persistent request for immediate discharge home despite foreseeable symptom escalation risk, or recommend continued inpatient hospice care to ensure safer symptom control in the setting of limited beds.

choice_1.choice: Arrange immediate discharge home with home hospice, documenting the patient’s informed, persistent preference for home death and providing the best feasible home symptom plan (e.g., scheduled medications, rescue doses, clear escalation instructions), acknowledging that rapid IV titration and guaranteed readmission are not available.

choice_2.choice: Recommend continued inpatient hospice care to maintain close monitoring and rapid IV titration for dyspnea control, explaining that discharge today would foreseeably increase suffering risk and that readmission cannot be assured; revisit the plan frequently and explore other ways to honor home goals when safer.
